prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Papers of James Taylor Ellyson, Accession #4130, Special Collections Dept., University of Virginia Library, Charlottesville, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: These items were given to the University of Virginia Library on January 9, 1953, by J. Taylor Ellyson Crump, of Richmond, Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the correspondence and related papers of James Taylor Ellyson (1847-1919), businessman and politician of Richmond, 1865, 1896-1910, ca. 1,500 items (6 Hollinger boxes, 2 linear shelf feet), and contains correspondence, news clippings, financial papers, political papers, Civil War service papers, invitations, and papers pertaining to the 1907 Jamestown Ter-Centennial Exposition.

A list of correspondents writing to Ellyson, with the dates of their letters, is available for this collection beginning on page two. A list of persons to whom Ellyson wrote begins on page 31 of this guide. Topics in the correspondence include: Ellyson's successful campaign for Lieutenant Governor in 1905, the Tennessee Railroad Company, the Old Dominion Building and Loan Association, the Joseph Bryan Memorial Association, the Jefferson Davis Memorial Association, the United Confederate Veterans, Richmond College, the Baptist Church, the Democratic party in Virginia and national politics, Confederate memorial associations, business, and personal affairs.

Ellyson, son of Henry K. and Elizabeth P. Ellyson, attended Columbia College, Richmond College, and the University of Virginia, graduating in 1869 and marrying Lora E. Hotchkiss, also in 1869. During the Civil War, he served in the Confederate army as a member of the 2nd Company of the Richmond Howitzers, surrendering with them at Appomattox and resuming his college work. Following his graduation, he entered into the business world of Richmond, becoming president of the city council, a member of the board of public interests, a state senator, 1885-1888, and served three terms as mayor of Richmond beginning in 1888.

Ellyson was Chairman of the State Democratic Party Committee for twenty-five years, Lt. Governor of Virginia for three terms, 1906-1918, and Governor for the Division of History, Education, and Social Economy for the Jamestown Exposition. He was also on the board of trustees for Richmond College, Chairman of the Richmond city school board, an executive officer of the Education Board of the Baptist General Association of Virginia, President of the State Baptist Association, vice-president of the Southern Baptist Convention, and a representative on the State Mission Board, the Orphanage Board, and Education Board.
